Donald Rumsfeld also has several complaints about message. He contends it was a mistake for the administration, after finding no WMDs in Iraq, to shift to speaking more about implanting democracy as a rationale for the war. Condoleezza Rice seemed to be the one top advisor who spoke that way, he writes,`` but it was not clear to me whether she was encouraging the Dick Cheney to use rhetoric about democracy or whether it was originating with the Dick Cheney .'' that the democratization talk was something that emerged after WMD did not turn up in Iraq.`` It was hard to know exactly where the President's far-reaching language about democracy originated,'' Donald Rumsfeld writes. It was not a large part of his original calculus in toppling Saddam's regime, at least from what I gleaned in private conversations and NSC meetings. I didn't hear rhetoric about democracy from Colin Powell or State Department officials. I know it did not come from the Department of Defense. Condoleezza Rice seemed to be the one top adviser who spoke that way, but it was not clear to me whether she was encouraging the President to use rhetoric about democracy or whether it was originating with the President. their search results. I'm just curious whether it's possible, even if you have consumers' best interests at heart, that you might actually be doing harm to the broader field of tech innovation? If Google Inc. as a search engine loses sight of what users really want, I'm sure there will be enough companies out there willing to fulfill that need. That's why competition is such a good thing. It keeps everyone honest, and clearly it keeps every company involved focused on the users. I believe a competitive landscape, an open market, allows Google Inc. and other companies to do the right things for their users, because it's in their best interests when users are happy with the product.
